comments.commentBody:
@nora01: "Corporations are like zombies: they have no soul, no morality, no remorse, no responsibility, and never die."

It need not be that way, and in the early days of corporations, their charters limited them to a specific business and a specific lifetime. Charters could be renewed but it was not automatic. One of the grounds for not renewing was if a corporation had violated the public interest.
I believe you meant to say histrionic times for surely that's what the tea party is.

I agree with the point, but why have the acronyms POTUS and SCOTUS become so popular in our times. They sound like names from a comic book. What is wrong with referring to the President or the Presidency, and the Supreme Court?
Beautify the language!

Everything Dole said is true and more, including all the other points in the editorial.

But we have to mention we live in historic times, when Senate GOP'ers activley consider down-sizing the DC Appeals Court bench in order to keep 3 vacancies from being filled by the Executive Branch, as the Constitution prescribes.

We would have been against FDR's famous attempt to increase the number of SCOTUS justices, and we are just as much against an attempt by GOP'ers to try a reverse move in this day and time.

The Senate has an advise and consent obligation regarding judicial confirmations, and GOP'ers are still the minority Senate party, with POTUS being (again) elected by historic margins.

GOP'ers have to work with the Executive who was elected to lead, no matter if he is from the other party - that's the way this country, and democracy, work.

The GOP cannot keep trying to negate two presidential elections because they lost; they damage the country, and democracy as a whole with their refusal to accept election results by obstructing the constitutional duties of other branches of government just because that branch is not under their party's control.

GOP'ers need to be cognizant of the un-precedented spectacle they are creating in front of the rest of the world, and listen to some party elders.

"Dole has always stood for accomplishing the people's business and has worked assiduously and constructively to serve all Americans."

You make that statement by comparison to the insanity running rampant in both houses of Congress. Dole was very right wing, and wasn't always "constructive," especially if you have a liberal POV. But he could certainly seem that way in light of what is happening today. I feel that calling Bob Dole looks back with rose-colored glasses.

Bravo to the sensible, no-nonsense, straight-to-the point Bob Dole.  Senator Dole has always stood for accomplishing the people's business and has worked assiduously and constructively to serve all Americans.  Thank you, Senator Dole, for saying what needs to be said. Were you and pragmatic Republicans back in command of the GOP, it would benefit the nation immensely.

The US should worry about national security given how information is bartered in the Asian nations through the use of money, compromising photos, and sex. But the Chinese military can hack into anything they want anyway, so perhaps it makes little difference.

Rather the number of successful acquisitions by Japanese companies of any major global firm can probably be counted on one hand (if that many). I'd feel more worried about both companies getting run into the ground by Softbank management that's primarily known for getting lucky and Sprint management which is remarkable in its ability to ignore customers.

And one has to wonder if Softbank had set aside the funds last year for this deal, since the price tag has just gone up by 25% due to the depreciating yen. Of course, Softbank's stock price has doubled due to the Abenomics bubble in Japan.

The more one looks, the more this looks like the return of the good ol' financial scam deals of the 80's than any synergy-based deal. The bubble has officially returned.

Perhaps the best use of Prof. Fish's waning years would be for him to acquire the values that might help him atone for the previous years.

He established himself as an intellectual celebrity by becoming the American franchisee for deconstructivism, probably the most evil and corrupt intellectual theory in history, in that it sought to devalue human intent, denying 200,000 years or more of intellectual progress.

Once secure on the intellectual A-list, Prof. Fish moderated his rhetoric, if not his underlying intellectual nihilism. His writings endlessly and archly (although admittedly with great erudition) pose profound questions, but deflate our expectations by ultimately denying the validity (or even possibility) of answers.

However, answers always exist, if a person or a society can clearly enunciate its values and goals. Prof. Fish's "on-the-one-hand-on-the-other-hand" approach ultimately makes no contribution.

I doubt that he needs to worry about retirement. If the household accounts run low, there'll always be a speaking engagement to plug the gap. He should sign up with Tom Friedman's speaker's bureau - they know there's always a market for intellectual charlatanry, if it can be made to sound profound.

Prof. Fish and the rest of us may benefit if he turns his formidable intellect to providing answers instead of questions. He should try it. It's never too late.

Some of us who are a bit Scandinavian (my grandmother was from Sweden) don't care if Obama schmoozes and backslaps. Those things are distasteful no matter who does them, and presidents with standoffish personalities are not doomed to failure except in the minds of needy reporters. Examples include Madison and Wilson, who disdained phony warmth, and had little of the real kind, either.

Far more distressing is Obama's seamless transition from Bush II, including dawdling in failed Asian wars (as Nixon did), domestic spying, handouts to investment banks and fossil fuels, and action against global warming that is rhetorical only.

Schmoozing is limited to the golf course, where Obama retreated with oil executives during the big Keystone Pipeline protest. Brewskis on the fairway with greed crazed plutocrats bent on destroying our climate seems to relax him. But then, the people didn't elect Mr. Obama. Wealthy corporations did, just as with Clinton, Bush, and Reagan. The Democratic base is not going to get suckered again next time, whether the corporate chosen candidates are charming or not.
We crave authenticity, and await an actual human such as Whitehouse or Inslee.
Perhaps with the NINE IRON it should have been META FORE!

I *had in mind* to disclose that I never said or heard the word LOGY. But there was *more in store* for us in this dandy of a Wednesday puzzle. Gary Cee certainly knows how to RUB it IN.

Actually, Deb, I think the whole idea of the central 31D was to RUB the word IN into the theme phrases to make them work. Once you do that, and the IN says "IN I GO," it all works.

TWOBALL and NINEIRON were very clever, then Gary TOSSES in their symmetrically placed META-FOUR for good measure.

I loved WENT TO POT, TRAIL BIKES and I SURRENDER. I won't SCHLEP out all the others that I liked today, but being a FERVENT music lover, I must close with the following triple play:

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dGkn91ywbsU

Sylvia McNair sings the aria "REJOICE greatly, O daughter of Zion" from HANDEL's "Messiah" with Neville Marriner on the podium.

Good night.
Peke: BEST in SHOW.

John, As for your avatar on this Humpday evening, I implore you, Do nat go there, bec when the Chips are down, the buffalo is empty!

WHH
Sorry:  In this case, the shoe fits, even if it does pinch.

it's really amazing that so many think of African Americans as a collective group. Believe it or not we are not all the same. Surely no one thinks Honey Boo Boo and her family represent all whites. You can look at any family and see many different classes of people let alone an entire group of people. Every family has one and sometimes two or three.
Isn't brainwashing wonderful.  JB would rather people suffer that two oleaders dare to cooperate.

@Daisy
The difference is that the Republicans have engaged in an unprecedented level of filibustering. You don't see the numbers for a given Congress hit triple digits until after the GOP became a minority in the Senate after the 2006 elections.
http://www.senate.gov/pagelayout/reference/cloture_motions/clotureCounts...

Merely as a function of being "empty seats," only the irrationally insane and grossly partisan would object to these seats being filled... right?

That's of course only if the Republican opposition [systemically obstructionists] railing against filling the vacated DC Court seats--- rather their blustery angst, is in direct correlation with that of the constitutional appointing designee and/or appointee just happens to be a Democratic President named Barack Obama... right?

Again I ask: Why are these people serving within "The People House"... Congress?

I know one of the 4,450 who has been audited numerous times and had to come down to DC to testify several times. He paid all his taxes and had a team of accountants to figure it out during the years he lived abroad. Now he also has a team of lawyers representing him to the Feds. He was just a regular citizen living overseas and having a checking account. Sure, he was wealthy, but that is not an automatic red flag of tax evasion. How was he supposed to pay his bills without a checking account in a Swiss bank if he lived in Zurich?

By the way, there has been no indication by the "court" that he is innocent before proven guilty, of that he is subject to any constitutional protections he would have in the legal system. This is the IRS. After the last audit, it was determined that he actually overpaid his taxes one year, but the accountants and Feds can't agree on how much because the tax laws are too complicated. No problem - his company can just keep paying the lawyers until it is all worked out. What a waste of time.
There is no question they will be heavily penalized if they haven't already.  As to incarceration, so far only one individual has been jailed & he allegedly was a whistleblower.

"A breakthrough came in 2009, after UBS, the largest Swiss bank, agreed to enter into a deferred-prosecution agreement. The bank turned over 4,450 client names and paid a $780 million fine after admitting to criminal wrongdoing in selling tax-evasion services to wealthy Americans."

Anyone know if any of the 4,450 were ever penalized (much less indcted) for tax evasion?

Oh please. Guarantee Moore will be rebuilt way before we've recovered. Thanks to the petty, cold-hearted actions of two of your Senators, Coburn and Inhofe, who voted against financing FEMA. And your two Republican congressmen, Bridenstine and Mullin, who voted against ANY relief money for the victims of Sandy. That's why so many here on the East coast have waited months to get any financial help.

But it's okay, my citizen sister, I bear you no ill will. .And I truly hope that everyone in Moore who is suffering get the help they need. All I ask is that you remember my comment the next time you go into the voting booth.

The only problem is that he will be a president who leads a party of full of nuts.

If voters elect him, he will pull the entire carriage of loons with him into DC. Those people who deny science, global warming, want to make abortion as hard as possible. People who hate, and I mean hate, gays and even latino people.

It's refreshing to see politicians take a break from politics.
President Obama has had his last campaign. As a true
independent voter I will seriously consider voting for Governor
Christie if I ever have the chance. It's nice to see someone
like Christie putting his state and the country above his
party.
My ex-inlaws are from Tom's River.  Is everyone in that town nasty?  Must be somethng in the water.

We will never quell the gun violence until we reinstate the right to bring a civil suit against gun manufacturers. distributors, and dealers for negligence when their weapons are involved in a crime.  The right for a victim to sue was abrogated in 2005 due to intense lobbying by Wayne LaPierre and the NRA, signed into law by President George W. Bush on 10/20/2005.   Bring back this cause of action and the trial lawyers will take them down the gun manufacturers and dealers.  I promise.
You mean the media created hysteria?

I agree and disagree, Mark.

If Christie runs, he would be a hard fit with anyone in the GOP considering running for President. Why should he play second fiddle to the likes of Rand Paul, Ted Cruz (if he even eligible), or Marco Rubio? Where are the elder statesmen in the party running in 2016? If Chuck Hegel, Dick Lugar, Jon Huntsman, or even Colin Powell were still in the party, maybe, but Lindsey Graham, Mitch McConnell, John McCain, and John Boehner are the titular party heads now. I don't think they have massive appeal.

Christie deserves to be at the top of the ticket if he runs with a Republican. No other person in the GOP could beat him in the general election.

He can also run in a cross-party ticket, perhaps with a Democrat at the top of the ticket or as a running mate. John McCain and considered running with Joe Lieberman before McCain settled on Palin.

I would not completely rule out the possibility of a third party win in 2016. Christie would be a strong contender, as would Bloomberg (already an independent).

Christie is right to leverage his "maverick-ness." No one likes the DC partisan hot house. "Independent" governors outside the DC circuit might have a strong chance in 2016 if they work outside of the RNC/DNC primary weeding process.

I lost my library--700 volumes--to a disastrous house fire in 2005. I was at retirement age, then, but I had never accepted the reality of retirement. Six years later I began to work as an process engineer in rural México. A big change from the Pacific NW! I still never think of retirement. Yes there is a loss of ability, in my case some mobility, but I am afraid to leave the satisfaction I experience here for for the uncertainty of trying to do something or nothing else in the hope that it would be equally or more satisfying.

I have no books now, except for a few on the natural and political history of the Sonoran Desert.
So were Herbert Hoover and Harry S Truman.

What in the world makes you think "the American people will never support - "Roe v Wade""? It's been the law of the land for - how many years???? As a female, I can assure you that most THINKING women DO support it because they can get pregnant by means of rape, incest, husbands who insist on sex without contraception so they are forced to bear ten children (You try it, once!), and so on.

Talk about small and petty; you'll certainly never be the editor of Harvard Law Review!
Have you been to post-Katrina New Orleans?

Huh? Christie is a Republican. A REAL Republican. You live in Idaho so you may have missed his exchange with a local reporter. Reporter Sarah Gonzalez asked him if he thought climate change may have contributed to the storm. Here's how it played out:

Her question:

"WNYC has documented several mistakes New Jersey Transit made getting ready for Sandy, and severe storms caused by climate change. Do you feel you did enough to prepare state agencies for climate change?"

Christie's response:

“Well first of all I disagree with the premise of your question because I don’t think there’s been any proof thus far that Sandy was caused by climate change. But I would absolutely expect that that’s exactly what WNYC would say, because you know liberal public radio always has an agenda. And so since I disagree with the premise of your question I don’t feel like I have to answer the rest of it.”

If you'd like to read more, including Christie relentless defense of NJ Transit's disastrous decision to leave hundreds of trains in low-lying Hoboken instead of moving them to higher ground, thereby costing NJ residents millions:

http://www.wnyc.org/blogs/transportation-nation/2013/may/24/parsing-chri...

Never forget basine: "liberal public radio has an agenda".
